fields.title: How to create all paths possible from a python dictionary?
fields.content:
I have a python dictionary where I'd like to output all possible paths from all key values. Here is a small scale example to visualize what I'm trying to do.
dictionary = {'parent':['child1','child2'], ‘child1’: ['child1_1','child1_2'], ‘child2’: ['child2_1','child2_2'], ‘child3’: [], 'child1_1'= ['child1_1_1', 'child1_1_2'],  'child1_1_1': [], 'child1_1_2': [], 'child1_2': [], 'child2_1': [], 'child2_2': [], 'child4'=[]}
And the output that I'd like to have is something like this:
parent/child1
parent/child1/child1_1
parent/child1/child1_1/child1_1_1
parent/child1/child1_1/child1_1_2
parent/child1/child1_2
parent/child2/child2_1
parent/child2/child2_2
parent/child3
parent/child4
.
.
.
Please note that I'd like to use it for a larger scale, so using 2 for loops I was able to output a path with parent and a 2 direct childs of it. But it doesn't work on larger scale, I think I need a for loop inside of a while true loop where I can check if a child doesn't have any childs of itself and it outputs me “Hey I'm the last one left and here is paths that are available to me" etc.
Thanks in advance and have a nice day.

C:/xfopencv-master/include/common/xf_axi.h:144: undefined reference to `cvIplImage(cv::Mat const&)'
and
C:/xfopencv-master/include/common/xf_axi.h:259: undefined reference to `cvIplImage(cv::Mat const&)

fields.title: Undefined javascript array to html [closed]
fields.content:
This question was caused by a typo or a problem that can no longer be reproduced. While similar questions may be on-topic here, this one was resolved in a way less likely to help future readers. Closed 24 mins ago. I started learning javascript and created a simple to-do web app to practice. However, an error that is breaking me apart is appearing, for example, i have an array with all the tasks which will store the tasks, then i will get the task content from the creation of the task and push it into the array and finally create the task element for the html part. But i dont know why, when the html part is created, the first element created always comes with two tasks, one saying what the content was and another saying undefined. The other tasks show up normal. As you can see, when i created task1 the undefined one showed up, and i dont know why this is hapening... And in the console, the array is working fine: Here is the relevant code: let add = document.querySelector("#add") let tasksArray = [] let taskContent = document.querySelector("#task-content") add.addEventListener("click", () => { let task = "" tasksArray.push(taskContent.value); for (let index = 0; index <= tasksArray.length; index++) { task += `
${tasksArray[index]} grade
` } document.querySelector(".tasks-list").innerHTML = task; console.log(tasksArray); })
Add new task
By my understanding of the code, the tasksArray[index] is returning undefined but still, why is it showing up two times, one correct and another undefined?? I have tried changing the position of the code various times or even trying to eliminate the task that said "undefined" but it didn't work. I dont really know how to fix this. I was expecting that the undefined task would disappear but it just would not.

fields.title: Suggestions and Comments for my Task-based wrapper methods for external library
fields.content:
I am working on C# application to communicate a Fingerprint Attendance Device. The external C# library provided for the device communication only contains synchronous methods, but they are blocking as they are without any async support. So, I started developing a wrapper library that wraps some of these methods into non-blocking asynchronous Task-based methods that can be awaited without blocking the UI thread. FYKI, I have no experience in writing these kinds of low-level asynchronous methods other than consuming existing ones.
The following code section has an example wrapper method ConnectAsync() that I have written on my own. I have used TaskCompletionSource based on the assumption that the target operation is mostly asynchronous and I/O bound operation as it involves a network call.
I want to know if my method is actually correct or not and do further possible optimizations here. I would welcome any rewrites of this method if I'm incorrect or inefficient.
For reference, the full signature of the target method Connect_Net is:
The following is the way I want to consume it:

fields.title: JWT - What if the refresh token is compromised?
fields.content:
As far as I understand a JWT token has two parts
access token (short validity)
refresh token (long validity)
The purpose of keeping the access token short lived is if it gets compromised, the user will not be access the resource after its expiry.
The purpose of keeping the refresh token long lived is if the access token gets expired, the refresh token can then be used to generate a new access token OR increase the expiry time of the access token.
My question is, what if the refresh token gets compromised? In that case what is the whole point of keeping the access token short lived? Because the hacker can then keep reissuing a new access token each time it gets expired using the stolen refresh token.
Can someone explain to me please?

fields.title: Quartz job works at night. How to stop its work during the day if the process has not completed?
fields.content:
Quartz job works by trigger 0 0 19-5 * * ? (every hour from 7:00 PM to 5:00 AM). Process may take a long time, more than 1 hour. Cron expression is a part of external configuration. How to graceful stop Quartz job after 5:00 AM if process continue works?
Even if we start last iteration at 4:00 AM, there is no guarantee that it will be completed in 1 hour. Also if we start the last iteration at 3:00 AM, there is no guarantee that it will complete in 2 hours.

fields.title: How to fetch parameters from GET URL in nodejs with two GET statements?
Deadlock when accessing HashSet unless Tokio mutex is used
fields.content:
I'm getting deadlocked, and I cannot figure out what's the issue.
The code doesn't work if I use std::Mutex (or parking_lot::Mutex), but it works when Tokio's async mutex is used.
My understanding is that this would imply that I'm holding the lock across the await points, but as far as I can tell, I'm not, but clearly, I'm doing something wrong, I just don't see it.
Here is a simplified version of the code:
The same code works if I use async RwLock form Tokio. This function is the only one "interacting" with IDs, so it is not that I am taking the lock "somewhere else" for too long.
As per Tokio docs:
As a rule of thumb, using a synchronous mutex from within asynchronous code is fine as long as contention remains low and the lock is not held across calls to .await
I think I am following these rules.

fields.title: How to reuse Excel workbooks?
fields.content:
I make models in Excel. The overall structure is fairly simple, although the models may include several sheets:
where
Business usually wants several different sets parameters, and being able to view the results for all this sets of parameters. The Model (Constants and Computations) would be the same for all the sets of parameters.
The customary solution for this is to design the Model, make $n$ copies of the Worksheet, feed the different sheets with the different parameters and collect, a.k.a copy paste, the results somewhere (1st flag) else, usually a $n+1$ Workbook.
The problem comes when the Model has to be modified, let it be the Constants or Computations, or even mode derived results are desired, the changes have to be propagated to the $n$ worksheets and pray that the ol' Ctrl-C,V does not break anything, and is done in the same cells.
What I desire is a way to factor the Model into a some sort of "master" workbook or set of sheets in a book, and other workbooks to be able to reference the functions, and if posible the whole process, not the cells, to reuse the computations for each set of parameters, to get the corresponding results.
I've tried to use VBA to factor sheet, but this means that I have to transform the sheet into VBA code, and takes away the flexibility that the Excel sheet gives, and might break when sharing with business, it ends to give a more fragile solution than copy/paste.
This models usually are not reused outside than for the task that they are made.

fields.title: Creating a terminal emulator on Windows systems (preferably C#)
fields.content:
On UNIX (mostly Linux I think) systems, creating a terminal emulator usually requires forking the current process and redirecting the output using ioctl and setting the stdin and stdout equivalent to the parent process. The pseudoterminal handles the communication between the GUI "terminal" and the actual shell program (/bin/sh) itself.
Windows seems to have had a legacy Console API to do this kind of thing, but it appears to be deprecated.
How would I go about this in something on Windows? (Preferably for C# because I'll be doing most of my work in Unity to use shaders and other nifty visual effects for this "terminal").
I haven't particularly tried anything as I'm still very unfamiliar with Windows API.

fields.title: Are typedef declarations to bare function types (ie: not function pointers) legal in C89/C90?
fields.content:
Let's consider the following code:
This compiles fine without warnings with GCC and compiler flags -std=c90 -pedantic -Wall -Wextra.
But K&R (2e) don't show such code in their book; they only ever usetypedefs for function pointers. (Their discussion on p147 is problematic, but that aspect is not the subject of this question.) I don't have access to the C89/C90 standard documents.
According to the C standards documents (C99 TC3 (ISO/IEC 9899:TC3) draft, 6.7.7 ¶7; C11 draft, 6.7.8 ¶7; C17 draft, 6.7.8 ¶7; text identical (modulo formatting) in all three documents):
All three of the following declarations of the signal function [from <signal.h>] specify exactly the same type, the first without making use of any typedef names.
For what it's worth, Wikipedia claims:
The C and C++ syntax [with typedefs for function pointer types] given above is the canonical one used in all the textbooks - but it's difficult to read and explain. Even the above typedef examples use this syntax. However, every C and C++ compiler supports a more clear and concise mechanism to declare function pointers: use typedef, but don't store the pointer as part of the definition. Note that the only way this kind of typedef can actually be used is with a pointer - but that highlights the pointer-ness of it.
[...]
The implication of their phrasing is that allowing typedefs for bare function types is a compiler extension but not sanctioned by the standards. Is that really so? My quote from the C99 TC3, C11, and C17 standards clearly demonstrates that such typedefs are legal at least since C99 TC3. Are typedef declarations to bare function types (ie: not function pointers) legal in C89/C90? Note that the example "given above" that Wikipedia refers to (not quoted here) is a C++ example, so it's also possible that it's always been legal in standard C but just not in C++.

fields.title: Question about Linux x64 Calling Convention
fields.content:
I was reading this page Linux x64 Calling Convention, but got confused about passing function parameters by registers and stack. It says:
Arguments 1-6 are accessed via registers RDI, RSI, RDX, RCX, R8, R9 before they are modified or via  offsets from the RBP register like so: rbp - $offset.
If the first 6 parameters are passed by registers, how come they can also be read/write from the stack? Is the first 6 parameters stored both in the registers and on the stack?
